Introduction

This policy sets out a framework for temporary workers and the principles that should be followed to ensure fair treatment of temporary workers and consistency across the Trust irrespective of the sites.

The Trust acknowledges that departments may experience staffing difficulties and in order to maintain service provision, may need to secure temporary staffing arrangements. Due consideration should be given to viable alternative options before any temporary workers are engaged, such as redeployment of substantive staff from areas which may be able to support.

The Trust may be required to employ additional workers during periods when there are unplanned shortfalls in resources through sickness absence or other leave types. Temporary resources may also be required at times when there is need to cover additional work for a short period of time or to provide cover for longer term absences, such as covering vacancies during the recruitment process or to resource projects where additional resourcing has been approved as part of a business case.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Ensure that the Mid and South Essex Foundation Trust (‘the trust') provides clear, consistent information and procedures for the engagement and use of temporary, agency, locum workers

Ensure that all relevant Trust staff have a clear understanding of the process of managing staff shortages and the utilisation of temporary workers throughout the Trust in the form of bank, agency and locum workers.
Minimise temporary worker costs and ensuring value for money where agency costs are necessary.
Ensure that the Trust is compliant with employment law.
Definitions

These individual's terms and conditions are provided by the employment agency. data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust

The Audit Committee is responsible for providing an independent and objective review on the adequacy of the Trust's system of internal control, including audit arrangements (internal and external), financial systems, financial information, assurance arrangements including governance, risk management and compliance with legislation.
MSE Approval Panel
The MSE Approval Panel is responsible for monitoring and to grant approval for
use of bank and agency staff. (Refer to Appendix A)
Chief Executive
The Trust's Chief Executive through the Chief People and Organisational Development Director is responsible for promoting and supporting the aims and objectives of this policy.
Operational Directors and Clinical Directors and Matrons

Operational Directors, Clinical Directors and Matrons are responsible for implementing this policy and ensuring that all Managers and temporary staff are aware of this policy and adhere to its requirements.
Managers are responsible for following:
The commissioning of temporary workers in line with this policy

Providing unfilled demand to the bank office 6-8 weeks in advance except in exceptional circumstances; for example, due to changes in staffing requirements, unplanned absence/events, increase in service demand etc.
Provide evidence of approval through the trust's MSE approval process (Appendix A)
Support the Temporary Staffing Team in offering local induction and shadow shifts to new bank-only workers.
Ensuring that local induction procedures are followed e.g. ward orientation, checklists

Monitoring compliance of their substantive staffs statutory and mandatory training and if it is necessary to do so then they should alert the Temporary Staffing Team who can restrict their bank bookings until they have undertaken the necessary training.
Providing feedback on individual bank / Agency workers when requested by the Temporary Staffing team
Report any incidents, investigations or concerns regarding a Temporary worker to Temporary staffing team.
Not directly engaging with agencies under any circumstances
Head of Temporary Staffing is responsible for:
Recruitment and retention of bank workers
Keeping the Temporary staffing policy up to date
Ensuring that induction programmes are in place and delivered
Monitoring the use of temporary workers and agencies and where appropriate, taking action to reduce the reliance on agency use
Ensuring NHS Framework Agencies are used if the use of an agency becomes necessary
Managing the management information for the Trust
Monitoring and managing the PSL's with the sites through review sessions and feed into relevant forums
Ensuring bank workers are informed of their statutory and mandatory training requirements and for monitoring compliance
Ensuring the Policy is followed in relation to additional staffing through Trust monitored KPIs
Managing the user accounts for the Bank Staff Booking System and the security of the system
Governance for the NHS Approved Frameworks, CQC and NHSi requirements.
Temporary Staffing Team is responsible for:
Liaising with bank workers to obtain availability
Liaising with department staff regarding bookings and allocation of work
Seek alternative options for obtaining staff when shifts remain unfilled including agency workers
Obtain evidence of checks on agency workers via the framework supplied checklist;
Administration tasks relating to the provision of the service
Maintaining frequent communication with departments seeking bank or agency cover
Maintaining up to date database for bank and agency workers
Ensuring that candidates provided are suitable for the role requested by keeping skills up to date on their profile and arranging interviews if necessary before being booked to a department.

Inform relevant department heads / in charge of any cancellation of a filled shift at the time of cancellation if it is within 48 hours, cancellations with greater lead time than  hours will show on Healthroster
Regularly checking that workers are suitably qualified for temporary roles
Bank workers
Bank workers are responsible for:
Complying with their Terms of Engagement
Reading and adhering to the Trust policies which will be explained to them within their welcome pack supplied by the Temporary Staffing Team

Booking training updates. Any pure bank worker who has lapsed with their update for Statutory/Mandatory training will be restricted from booking shifts until their training is complete and the temporary worker will be contacted to complete and update their training. If training remains lapsed for a period of 6 months, then the temporary worker may be removed from the bank.
Maintaining professional registration if applicable to the role
Booking shifts via the booking platform provided i.e. locums nest for Medics or Allocate Me/EOL for other staff groups
Undertake local induction for each department
Maintain reliability
Adhere to the Trust values
Complying with the working time directive as laid out in the rostering policy

Ensuring their reliability is kept to the highest possible standard when booking shifts, once three cancellations are made within a 3 month rolling period a review of reliability will be undertaken by the Temporary Staffing Team to offer support where possible
Ensuring that shifts not finalised by managers within 3 months are appropriately escalated to the Temporary staffing team
Agency workers
Agency workers are responsible for:
Complying with Trust policies and procedures
Undertake local induction for each department
Maintain reliability
Adhere to the Trust values
Ensuring that they are well orientated to the Trust and keeping up to date with the team they are working with by undertaking local inductions within each
department they work
Temporary Staffing Practice Development Nurses are responsible for:
Undertaking shortlisting and interviews for bank nurses and Healthcare assistants
Reviewing and advising on all complaints involving clinical issues
Ensuring the complaints process is followed in relation to all clinical incidents
Act as Clinical Lead support for bank clinical workers
Undertaking pregnancy risk assessments for bank workers
Facilitating the Bank HCA Training courses
Liaising with corporate nursing team for support in relation to the above responsibilities.
Conditions of the use of temporary workers

Prior to requesting temporary resources all other options should be considered. Temporary workers should only be engaged as a last resort after considering all other staffing alternatives i.e. redeployment from other departments that may be in a better staffing position.
The guidance for the trust approval process must be followed (Appendix A)

Each department must consider staff planned absence such as annual leave and maternity leave, as well as a certain amount of unexpected leave such as sickness, carer's leave etc. Temporary workers should not be used to cover annual leave or study leave except in exceptional circumstances following a local risk assessment taking into account vacancy factors.

Temporary workers should not be used as a long-term solution to staffing shortages and should never be used as an alternative to recruiting to an identified permanent vacancy but can be used whilst active recruitment is undertaken.

‘Temporary' refers to a period of a few days or weeks and Temporary workers must not be engaged for any longer than a 12-week continuous period. If a department utilises temporary workers for longer period, then it should be reviewed and a plan formulated to move to a more permanent solution.

If there is not an identified permanent vacancy but cover is required for longer than a 12-week continuous period. The department manager should then contact the Permanent Recruitment team and their HR Business Partner for advice on alternative staffing solutions such as fixed term contracts.
Rate negotiations with agencies should only be handled by the temporary staffing team.
When to use temporary workers
Temporary workers should not be used as an alternative to recruiting to an identified vacancy. Reasons for temporary staffing may include the following:
When there is a vacancy, this should only be whilst active substantive recruitment to the role is undertaken
When there are unplanned absences such as sickness within the department that cannot be covered by the remaining workforce
When there has been appropriate authorisation to prevent the service delivery being at risk
An increase in volume of work (major incident)
When there is patient or health and safety risks affecting staff/service users
If a substantive new starter is delayed for various reasons
This list is not exhaustive and is subject to change; these situations are planned and appropriate vacancy cover should be sought prior to temporary staffing requests being made.
Management of temporary workers performance/conduct

Local managers are expected to plan what duties are to be undertaken and monitor the workers performance and conduct. Managers have a responsibility to ensure that concerns are raised and addressed where appropriate. Managers should report evidence based concerns with regard to performance or conduct to the Temporary Staffing Team. Dependent on the nature of the concern or allegation, Temporary Staffing in consultation with the Human Resources Business Partner will advise on the relevant action to be taken.
Cancellations

Temporary workers should only book shifts that they are available to work, however it is understood that occasionally they may need to cancel a shift. The worker will need to give the Temporary Staffing team as much notice as possible.

After three cancellations of shifts within a three-month rolling period, regardless of lead time, temporary workers will be contacted for a review by the Temporary Staffing Team to explore the reasons for cancellations and identify any support measures needed to maintain consistent attendance. During the review meeting undertaken by the appropriate manager, it will be discussed about how best to avoid cancellations which can have a detrimental effect on services within the sites.
At the review meeting potential measures that will be discussed are:
Only booking of shifts 24 hours in advance (this will mean all future bookings are cancelled to comply with the support measure)
Limiting working to particular areas
Further training or shadow shifts
Referrals to Occupational Health
Further issues with cancellations and reliability could possibly lead to no further bank work being offered.
Timesheets
With the  current  exception  of  Doctors,  all  bank  duties  should  be  captured  on HealthRoster and Timesheets should be finalised within 3 months of being worked to be paid.
Professional registration

All professional temporary workers have an obligation to maintain their professional registration. Lapsed registrations will result in staff being refused work and ultimately being removed from the bank
Training and local inductions for pure bank staff

All temporary bank workers are engaged on a Casual Worker Agreement and will be required to attend the Trust's Corporate Induction day. Specific individual training requirements (role specific) will be assessed and booked during the recruitment and bank induction process.

Temporary workers are afforded the same training opportunities as permanent members of staff. All statutory and mandatory training that is relevant to their role will be paid, however, any additional training for development purposes will not be paid.

Staff with both a bank and substantive assignment will have their personal training and development plan provided by their line manager. Where there are issues of concern or identified development needs it is important that a close liaison exists between the appropriate line manager and the temporary staffing team. Performance issues in a bank workers substantive post may result in them being unable to undertake bank work and will be at the discretion of their line manager.
Temporary staffing for locum doctors
This policy applies to all grades of temporary and locum doctors.

All Medical shifts should be advertised via the Locums Nest platform for bank, and should the need arise, and appropriate approval has been received escalated through to agency via the systems cascade function.
Shifts will then be available to view by our PSL of medical agencies and CV's can be forwarded against an advertised job.
Any proposed candidates should fall beneath the NHSi cap in terms of cost and the payment method of direct engagement should be considered above all else before forwarding CV's.

Anything outside of these parameters should go through the trust approval process (Appendix A). Every effort should be made to ensure that locum doctors are cost effective and once in place, if possible, continue to search for cheaper alternatives.
Management arrangements for locum doctors

The Chief People and Organisational Development Director (delegated to the Head of Temporary Staffing) is responsible for ensuring that there are adequate systems in place for recruiting and appointing locum doctors.

Temporary Staffing Team, as a central resource, will assist Directorates in the recruitment and appointment of locums. It will co-ordinate and agree contracts with agencies and ensure that there are systems in place to monitor their performance.

Temporary Staffing will ensure that adequate records are kept and that systems for locum verification and performance review are in place. Clinical Directors in conjunction with their management team are responsible for ensuring that there are adequate numbers of medical staff present to provide safe and effective patient care.
Planned leave and unplanned absence for locum doctors
Annual and study leave

Locums should ideally not be appointed to cover planned, predictable leave for medical staff (including leave for holidays, exams and study), however such leave is essential for wellbeing and continuing professional development, and locums may be necessary to ensure such leave can be taken while providing sufficient staffing to maintain departmental patient safety standards.

Prospective internal cover is in place across all junior doctor rosters in the Trust. This means that cover for all on-call / out of hours duties, which an individual doctor is rostered for on the dates they propose to take annual or study leave, must be arranged by that individual, by swapping shifts with other junior doctor colleagues participating in the roster. A locum should not be sought to cover these shifts.
Since there should be ample warning of such a situation occurring, wherever possible locum agencies will not be used and internal locum cover will be arranged.

For prospective cover arrangements to operate efficiently, it is incumbent on clinical teams to manage their resources effectively, ensuring the minimum medical staffing required to the service delivery is not compromised.
Unforeseen absence – sickness, compassionate leave

If an ad hoc locum is needed at short notice to cover unforeseen absence (e.g.: sickness) the division will be responsible for loading the shifts into Locums Nest. Should the shifts require cascading this should be done in Locums Nest at the point of entry and agency usage should go through the trust approval process (Appendix A), not gaining appropriate approval could result in a locum not being paid.

Temporary Staffing Team will be responsible for seeking a locum for any on- call / out of hour's rostered slots that require cover. As a matter of course, bookings will be placed with locum agencies through the LMS portal. The Temporary Staffing Team, with support from the Clinical Lead for the department concerned will take all reasonable steps to identify a suitable internal locum first, before resorting to locum agencies. This is a more cost effective way of filling the vacancy and supports safer clinical care, by employing our own doctors, who are familiar with the workings of the Trust and may have been involved in the clinical care and management of the patients.
Remuneration for locum doctors
All additional locum duties carried out by employed medical staff will be paid at an hourly rate as set out by the trust.

Rates of pay are not open to negotiation by individual doctors. Chief People and Organisational Development Director is responsible for setting rates of pay. Clinical Directors are not authorised to negotiate any variations to the pay scales set.
Any requests to pay outside of the Trust agreed rates must be sought at Executive Level through the trust approval process (Appendix A).

Pay will be weekly providing shifts are appropriately recorded in the trusts bank platform and approved by the relevant authorisers in the department. These should be done within 90 days of the shift being worked.
Breaks for locum doctorsas per agreed MSE break definition)

A 30-minute unpaid break should be taken for every 6 hours of work to be taken; any shift exceeding 12 consecutive hours in length should have a minimum of 60 minutes unpaid break time during the shift. This can be broken down into multiple shorter breaks.
Breaks must be taken during a shift and are not to be taken at the beginning or end of a shift (e.g. starting later or finishing earlier)
All breaks taken should be submitted onto the Locums Nest digital timesheet by the worker for deduction which will be reviewed by the department approver.

If you were unable to take a break, enter the break time in your digital timesheet as zero minutes, underneath adding a comment confirming that you were required to work as a result of service demand. Please provide as much detail as possible.
The use of the comment box when submitting zero minutes break will assist the Trust in processing your timesheets in a timely manner and minimise rejections or amendments.
Before a timesheet is fully approved to go to payroll, your department approver should contact you to discuss any amendments to your timesheet before they are made.
Opting Out of Working Time Regulations
It is highly likely that doctors employed by the trust, undertaking additional duties will exceed 48-hour working under WTR

It is important to note that opt out relates solely to the average number of hours worked per week over a 26-week rolling period. Doctors cannot opt out of the requirement to have 11 hours continuous rest (off duty) in any  hour period.
Doctors Bank, Clinical Directors and Consultants must take this into account when considering who might be suitable to provide additional cover.
Cancellation of locum shifts

Doctors need to process the cancellation via Locum's Nest. If the shift is less than 48 hours till start time they need to contact the department directly to notify them of the cancellation. Reliability is an important factor and cancellations will lead to no further work being offered.
Supervision

There are times when it may be appropriate for temporary medical staff to supervise others junior to themselves, this should only be in circumstances where no other alternative is available and only once fully orientated to the department and Trust. This should be reviewed with the responsible officer (Medical Director or lead consultant) and an appropriate risk assessment undertaken.
Timesheets
As with other staff groups, Medical locums will have a period of up to  days to claim for a shift worked, anything after this time will no longer be claimable.
Training requirements
This policy is in immediate effect from its agreement date. Advice and support on the implementation of this policy is available via the Temporary Staffing Team.
Monitoring and audit

Management information on the use of temporary workers will be supplied to the Trust on a regular basis by the workforce information team. The information supplied will be used to monitor individual Directorate's use of temporary workers.
Managers should review bookings for temporary workers on an on-going basis. The reviews should address the following:

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
The continuing need for the work to be covered
Whether alternatives have now become available for consideration

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the HR Policy Working Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local HR guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the HR Policy Control group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix H)
Appendix A: MSE Approvals process
As we become one organisation it is important that we have one set of processes so that we can help to ensure there is equity throughout the organisation.
One of the organisation's objectives is to;
Be effective and efficient with all our resources, creating an organisation that residents and staff can rely on for the long-term
The processes set out on the following pages, to support the process flow charts attached at Appendix C are to help the organisation to deliver this objective.
Both this document and the flow charts cover the approval processes for all substantive and temporary workforce requests for all staffing groups.
During 2019/20 we have implemented systems that ensure all of the organisation can recruit temporary and permanent staff in the same way. As a reminder these systems are;
TRAC – For substantive and fixed term recruitment
Locums Nest – For Medical Bank bookings
LMS – For Medical Agency and Direct Engagement bookings E-Pay – For payment of Medical WLI's
Health Roster – for Nursing Bank and Agency bookings Health Roster – for all other Bank Bookings
Selenity – for Expenses

Approval should be taken by those who have responsibility for the budget in question and the new controls reflect this principle. They also encourage wherever possible, for services to plan as far ahead as possible, so there is maximum opportunity to source the most efficient solution for the provision of resources.
Medical Bank and Agency

It is expected that the Deputy Director of Operations (DDO) and Clinical Director (CD) are managing the use of temporary workforce solutions as part of their financial and operational responsibilities and they will be held accountable for this. The managing director will be responsible for ensuring that care group performance overall is managed.
Bank
From st April 2020 the organisation has aligned medical bank rates.

Where the service are looking to fill shifts within their budgeted establishment with bank at the agreed MSE rate the Directors of Operations (DDO) and/or clinical director for the relevant service can approve the booking request. They should still consider whether the requirement for filling is absolutely required, cognisant they are accountable for the financial performance of their services.

MSE Bank rates are expected to be used in all circumstances. Any requests to vary this requires Chief People and Organisational Development and Chief Finance Officer approval. A risk assessment (Appendix A), must be completed and submitted to Mse.mseagencyapproval@nhs.net
Medical Agency

Where a shift remains unfilled by bank and the DDO/CD has deemed the need for this to be filled through an Agency worker, the request should be ‘cascaded' to the LMS platform to await approval by the relevant forum.
Immediate and short term requirements (less than 1 week booking required in the next 7 days)

Immediate and short term medical agency requests must be approved through local care group approval process (to be determined by each Managing Director), but still using the Trustwide risk assessment form at Appendix A.

Where the resulting proposed Agency booking is at a rate that exceeds the NHSI cap +50% rates (see Appendix D), this must be approved in advance of the booking by the Chief Finance Officer / Chief People and Organisational Development Officer, and the Chief Executive where the rate is above £100. This will require a completed and approved risk assessment (see Appendix A) to be submitted to Mse.mseagencyapproval@nhs.net Subject: Immediate Agency Rate Request (above cap)
Planned medical agency bookings

Planned Medical agency requests must be approved by the Medical Agency and WLI virtual Panel for the Trust. To request agency a risk assessment must be completed (appendix A), with prior approval from the Clinical Director or Deputy Director of Operations for the service, submitted to Mse.mseagencyapproval@nhs.net Subject: Planned Agency Rate Request

Where the resulting proposed Agency booking is at a rate that exceeds, the NHSI cap+50% rates, this must be approved in advance of the booking by the Chief Finance Officer / Chief People and Organisational Development Officer, and the Chief Executive where the rate is above £100. This will require a completed and approved risk assessment (see Appendix A) to be submitted to Mse.mseagencyapproval@nhs.net Subject: Planned Agency Rate Request (above cap)
All approvals are time limited and should any extension to this be required, the process must be followed again. It is not expected that any approval request exceeds 3 months.
Waiting list initiatives

There is no service budget for WLI's. These require prior approval before any commitment is made to individuals. Requests for WLIs are to be considered for approval by the Medical Agency and WLI virtual Panel. An additional list may only be booked once the request has been approved. To request approval the form at Appendix B must be completed.

WLI's are considered to be exceptional, and should relate to the delivery of cancer and 52 week constitutional standards. There is an expectation that the service will be able to show consideration of demand and capacity modelling to explain the need for the WLI session(s) over and above approved job plans as part of their application.

Approval must be sought in advance of establishing a list of patients and committing the clinician to the session. Where the list requires multiple clinicians / support, this must be fully outlined at the approval stage.

To submit a claim the clinician must complete a timesheet on ePay and attached to this they must supply the evidence that the session was approved. Without evidence of prior approval, sessional claims will not be paid.
Nursing bank and agency
Budget holders will utilise Health Roster which includes approved funded establishments rosters, to determine their bank fill requirements.

If there is a need to cascade to Agency, or to have exceptional bank shifts to address clinical grounds such as specialing, these must be approved by the Care Group Director of Nursing, after considering the staffing levels across the organisation and other mitigations available.

Any Agency approvals that result in an above Cap booking being proposed must be approved by the Chief Executive, Chief Finance Officer or Chief People and Organisational Development Officer prior to the booking being made. This request will be made by the temporary staffing team, and submitted to Mse.mseagencyapproval@nhs.net Subject: Nursing Agency Rate Request

There will be a retrospective review of fill rates, Agency bookings and additional shifts at the Trust wide nursing review meeting. This will be chaired by the Chief Nursing Officer on an at least monthly basis.
Other bank and agency and interim management arrangements
For all other bank the Director for Operations or Clinical Director for the service, or Executive Director lead for corporate services can approve the bank shift if it is within budget.
Requests for bank not in budget must go to the Chief Finance Officer for Approval, submitted to dawn.scrafield@nhs.net

Requests for Agency or Interim Management arrangements that are within budget and comply with the NHSI cap rates can be approved by the budget holder, the arrangements will be completed by the Temporary staffing team.

Requests which are more than budget or higher than NHSI cap+50% rates (see appendix D) must be approved by the Chief Finance Officer and Chief People and Organisational Development Officer. An e-mail summarising the following must be submitted to Mse.mseagencyapproval@nhs.net by the budget holder for consideration;
- Duration of request
- Hourly rate of request
- Reason for request
- Available budget for request
Substantive and fixed term recruitment

For a clinical vacancy that is within budgeted establishment and the request is a like for like replacement, this request needs to be put on TRAC and approved by the budget holder, followed by the relevant finance manager before being able to go out for advert.

For a non-clinical like- for-like replacement, the process is the same, with the exception that once entered in TRAC and approved by budget holder and finance manager, the post will be considered by a virtual vacancy panel. This will be a light touch process and is just to ensure the replacement is in line with the strategic direction of the organisation, and that there is no one on the ‘at risk' list that could be re-deployed into the role before advertised. The budget holder/requester does not have to attend this.

For proposed skill mixes, for all types of posts, these will need to be considered by the Vacancy Control panel. An application for change must be drafted to set out the change to be considered at the panel. The form in Appendix G must be completed and submitted to your finance business partner for finance approval, before they submit to the Vacancy Panel. This must be signed off by the budget holder and the Deputy Director of Operations/Clinical Director/Head of Nursing for the Division (Executive Director for Corporate). This is for all changes in establishment.
Investment Group
All requests for new investments must be presented for consideration by the investment group.
The need for the investment must fulfil one or more of three criteria;
- There is a critical safety need for the investment
- The investment supports one of the Organisations service transformation priorities
- The case is an invest to save opportunity to deliver efficiencies in the organisation

Investment Committee happens on a monthly basis, and the case must have Managing Director support and be signed off by the Finance Director Sponsor before being presented to the Committee. The investment group templates can be found at Appendix H.
